provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799-1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from his collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 73 (£1.2s. to "Streetly, Strang Street," probably an error, confusing name and address, for John Clark Strange); Strange by 1863; possibly the work offered by the dealer Francis Harvey in a catalogue of c. 1865 for £6.6s.; a "Mr. Kennedy" of Boston; Gorden Kennedy, sold in July 1932 to the Rhode Island School of Design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The subject is based on Matthew 3:16. At the bottom center of the design stands a nearly nude Christ, facing forward and looking down. He wears only a loincloth. His left leg is bent backward and on tiptoe, and his arms are bent at his sides with his hands together in a gesture of prayer. He has long, slightly curly hair and a beard. A suffusion of light surrounds his legs and head, where it forms a slight halo. To the left of Christ, facing away but looking up, is John the Baptist. He wears a furry animal skin belted around his waist like a toga. He has short, curly hair and a beard. He raises his arms at 135 degrees, palms up and fingers spread. From his right hand, he drops water onto Christ's head to baptize him. His mouth is partly open; he may be speaking or praying. His right leg is bent and on tiptoe. To the left of John the Baptist kneels a group of five figures. The frontmost figure in the group is an old man with long hair and a beard. He is gowned and bends forward, facing right and down. His right leg and his right arm are both visible and bent. Behind the old man, the leftmost figure is that of a gowned woman who appears to wear her hair in a bun. She faces right and slightly forward, and may be looking at John the Baptist or Christ. Her mouth may be slightly open. The figure immediately to the right of the woman is a female(?) child, possibly with long hair. She looks to the right and forward. The rightmost figure behind the old man is another female(?) child, probably with long hair. Only the top of her face and head are visible. She looks down and to the right. Kneeling to the right of the old man is what appears to be a nude boy with short, curly hair. His right leg is bent under him, while his left leg is bent upward, so that his right foot is flat against the river bottom. He faces to the right and slightly forward. His arms appear to be at his side and bent upward. He may have his hands together in a gesture of prayer or supplication. In the bottom left corner of the design stands a group of four figures, perhaps a family. The leftmost figure is that of a gowned man with short, curly hair and a beard. He faces away and looks up to his right. His right arm is at his side but bent, the palm vertical and fingers spread in a gesture of surprise. Both of his feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown and may be slightly on tiptoe. The figure standing second from the left in this group is a gowned woman with long, curly hair. She may be wearing a veil over her hair. Her arms are at her sides but bent upward, with her hands together in a gesture of prayer. She faces right and forward, looking slightly upward. The figure standing second from the right is likely a child, given its height, though its gender is indeterminable. It wears a gown and faces forward, looking up and to the right. Its left arm is raised between the vertical and 135 degrees, palm up. The rightmost figure of the group is a child, probably female, with long, curly hair. She wears a gown, the hem of which swirls around her calves. Her left foot is on tiptoe, and she faces away, looking up and to the right. Her arms are raised vertically, palms up. To the right of Christ kneel two figures, most likely a mother and her child. The child kneels, facing left and looking down. He (?) has short, curly hair and may be nude. His arms are bent upward with his hands together in a gesture of prayer or supplication. To the right kneels a gowned woman facing left and looking down. Her hair is pulled back in a bun. She bends forward, almost hunched over. Her arms are wrapped around her child, with her fingers interwoven, perhaps in a gesture of prayer or supplication. In the bottom right corner of the design stands a group of four gowned figures. The leftmost figure is a child, perhaps female, with long, curly hair. She faces away, but looks up and to the left. Her left leg is bent backward at the knee and her left foot is on tiptoe. Both feet are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her arms are at her sides but bent upward, palms out as though in a gesture of surprise. The figure standing second from the left is an old man with long hair and a beard. He faces left and looks down. His arms are bent upward with his hands together in a gesture of prayer or supplication. The figure standing second from the right is a man with long hair and a beard. He faces left and looks up. The rightmost figure of this group is an old man his long hair and a beard. He faces left and looks up. His arms are at his sides and bent upward, with his palms vertical but not touching. This gesture suggests either surprise or prayer. Both his feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown. All seventeen figures at the bottom of the design kneel or stand in a river or stream, most likely the Jordan River. The river winds through a landscape in the background with a small mountain or large hill on either side of the composition. On the left bank of the river are a number of leafy trees and perhaps some grass. Trees and other indeterminate vegetation are visible on the right river bank as well. Two flocks of sheep graze along the riverbank on the left and just below the mountain on the left. A small building, probably a house, is visible at the base of the left mountain, with a chimney and at least one window. The sky backing the scene may be slightly cloudy, with coloring that suggests a sunrise or sunset. At the top center of the image is a golden radiance. In the center of this radiance, facing down, flies a dove, likely representing the Holy Ghost. To the left of the dove are at least 23 hovering or flying figures. Some of these may be wingless angels, putti, or cherubs. The leftmost figures in this group include three gowned adults, most likely female, with flowered garlands or wreaths in their hair. Their bodies are horizontal and face right, with one facing away. Two of these figures carry infants in their right arms, which are bent and at their sides. The top right grouping is of nude children, perhaps male and cherubs, putti, or wingless angels, mostly facing right and down. The bottom right grouping includes a number of figures with garlands or wreaths on their heads, kneeling and facing right and down. To the right of the dove are at least 14 hovering or flying figures. Some of these figures may be wingless angels, putti, or cherubs. The leftmost group appears to consist of nude, cherub-like child figures, upside down and facing right. The bottom central group contains mostly kneeling figures, facing left and down. The kneeling figures may be gowned. The top central group is a pair of sketchy figures, of indeterminable age and gender, embracing each other. The rightmost grouping contains three adult female figures, with long, curly hair, facing left and with their bodies horizontal. Two of these women carry nude children in their arms, which are at their sides and bent to cradle the children. Another nude child is seen from behind, raising its arms vertically to greet the child to the right.
